awd_titl_txt: Synergistic or Antagonistic Effects of Polymer/Surfactant Supramolecular Assembly on the Colloidal Depletion Force
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1608003
PI: Tilton, Robert

When microscopic "colloidal" particles are suspended in a solution containing polymers, the polymers tend to be excluded from the gaps between particles. This exclusion gives rise to a force called the depletion force, which can draw particles together to form aggregates.  Some industrial processes take advantage of the depletion force by promoting aggregation of contaminant particles to remove them from solution.  However, the depletion force may be undesirable in other processes where ingredients must remain in solution, such as paint pigment particles or active agents in pharmaceuticals. Such liquid products must be formulated to prevent depletion-induced aggregation. When ionic surfactants are also present in the polymer solution, they can bind to the polymers and alter the depletion force in ways that are not completely understood. This project will examine various kinds of polymer/surfactant mixtures to better understand how polymer-surfactant binding influences the depletion force and the stability of the suspension. A colloidal probe atomic force microscope will be used to measure the depletion force in the polymer/surfactant mixtures. The results of the project will be useful to engineers who manufacture and process colloidal fluids, including paints, coatings, topical medications, and personal care products. The project will provide research opportunities for students at various academic levels, including middle school students who participate in the university's Physics Concepts Programs by designing experiments to examine the physical chemistry of liquid product formulations. 

This project will examine the role of polymer/surfactant complexation on depletion forces in colloidal suspensions. Colloidal forces in polymer/surfactant mixtures will be measured by colloidal probe atomic force microscopy. The project will reveal how complexation between ionic surfactants and either nonionic polymers or oppositely charged polyelectrolytes can amplify or suppress depletion forces. Experimental data will be interpreted in terms of a model that predicts depletion forces based on polymer/surfactant complex stoichiometry, charge and size. Results will be correlated with colloidal stability phase diagrams for a series of systems that represent canonical categories of polymer/surfactant association behavior. The outcomes of the project will benefit industrial practice where complexation is used in multicomponent liquid mixtures to produce novel material properties and products with diminished environmental impacts.

por.por_cntn:
Many commercially important fluid products are based on suspensions of colloidal particles in a liquid. Common examples are paints and many food products.  Having sizes ranging from a few nanometers to a few micrometers, colloidal particles exhibit properties that are ?in between? those of molecules and bulk materials. Like molecules, but unlike bulk materials, they can be suspended in liquids. Whereas molecules dissolved in a liquid will remain dissolved in principle forever, suspended colloidal particles will normally aggregate and settle out of the suspension, given enough time. Because of their small size, colloidal particles are suspended by the forces of Brownian motion.  When colloidal particles collide under the random action of Brownian motion, they may stick to each other and aggregate, if the forces that act between the particles are attractive, or they may survive the collision without aggregating if the particles exert repulsive forces on each other.  One engineers the stability of a colloidal suspension by choosing the type and concentration of various additives that control the forces that act between colloidal particles. These are referred to as ?colloidal forces? and are fundamental to the field of colloid science and engineering. These forces can have dramatic effects, such as converting a fluid suspension into a semi-solid gel.

This research considered a type of colloidal force known as the depletion force. When polymers or other macromolecules are added to a colloidal suspension, they rearrange themselves around the particles when those particles are driven into close proximity by Brownian motion. The rearrangement is such that polymers are depleted from the gap where the particle surfaces are closest together, and this creates a pressure difference that attracts the particles to each other.  If this depletion attraction is strong enough, it may cause the particles to aggregate.  Polymers are commonly added to fluid products to control their viscosity. It is also common for these products to contain surfactants (?detergent? molecules) to control their surface tension or to serve as solubilizing agents that allow water-insoluble molecules to be added to a water-based product.  Mixtures of polymers and surfactants are common. In some situations, polymers and surfactants interact with each other in ways that this research team proposed would strengthen the depletion attraction. Under such circumstances, adding polymers and surfactants to a formulation would have consequences far beyond the intended reasons for adding these components in the first place.

This fundamental research project used colloidal probe atomic force microscopy to measure colloidal forces for a series of polymer/surfactant mixtures that represent distinct categories of polymer/surfactant interaction. In some systems, polymers and surfactants bound to each other to create new self-assembled structures in the liquid.  In another system, the polymers and surfactants repelled each other. The key result of this research was the discovery that polymer/surfactant interactions synergistically strengthened depletion attractions, even for quite different modes of polymer/surfactant interaction. Often, strong depletion attractions occurred in mixtures when no attractions were detectable with either the surfactant or polymer acting alone. The system where polymers and surfactants repelled each other exhibited rich behaviors where the attraction was synergistically enhanced under some conditions and suppressed under other conditions. Thus, this system exhibited both synergistic and antagonistic effects.

Force measurements were complemented by a variety of spectroscopic, light scattering and electrochemical probes to measure the physical chemical properties of the structures that were formed in the various polymer/surfactant mixtures. These properties were used to explain why the mixtures had their observed effects on depletion forces, and revealed that different mixtures could have a similar overall effect (synergistic enhancement of depletion attractions) but for significantly different reasons.  The overarching intellectual significance of the work was to establish how and why important categories of polymer/surfactant mixtures produce effects on colloidal forces that would never have been predicted based on the behavior of either component acting alone.

This work provides broader economic impacts by guiding and streamlining the formulation of new high performance colloidal commercial products in industries as diverse as paints and coatings, agrochemicals, personal care and household liquids, pharmaceuticals and foods. It has broader societal  impact by contributing to the diversity of the STEM workforce. It provided research training for one female Ph.D. Chemical Engineering student and three female undergraduate Chemical Engineering research students.

Further impacts were achieved in education. Insights gained from this research were incorporated into a new course developed and delivered by the principal investigator at Carnegie Mellon University on "Formulation Engineering". The course had both lecture and laboratory components, and student teams were tasked to design their own surfactant-based product that would meet diverse performance objectives, aesthetic requirements and cost constraints. Students completing this course learned how fundamental knowledge of colloidal and surfactant phenomena, complemented by statistical methods, enables the  efficient design of value-added fluid products.
